column4: it won't look inside the folders because of the charcters?  What?

I litteraly have thousands of files to rename so a windows partition can read them. they have ":" and "/" in the file names that windows can't read. So I need to go through one dir and all is subs and rename the files.
I have a command that will rename the files in the current dir and all subs
But it will not do it in a dir that has "(" in its name. They all do because they are dates ie "(2009)"
so, from any of those directories, does   rename s/\:/--/ *:*   do what you want?
When i try to use the loop it says unexpected "(" or something to that affect
so, it appears as though your "sh -c  SomethingWithAParen" is the problem?
what does  "rename s/\:/--/  /path/to/a/file/with:colon"  do?  Something wrong?
just get rid of "sh -c" in the command then -- find . -xdev -type d -exec sh -c 'cd {} ; pwd ; rename s/\:/--/ *:* ' \;
I suspect you should    find -type f -exec rename s/\:/--/ {} \;   or something like that.
better, only run that for files with colon in the name:   find -type f -name \*:\* -exec rename s/\:/--/ {} \;   or something like that.
